results.title: The Laws of drag in fluid of high and low viscosity (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Quentin Brown, Kevin Smith and Educational Films Service
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Fluid Dynamics of Drag”.
Illustrates drag at very low Reynolds Number; Stokes Law; drag at high Reynolds Number; similitude low connecting drag coefficient and Reynolds Number; boundary layers; laminar and turbulent regimes.

results.title: Some curious experiments (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Quentin Brown, Kevin Smith and Educational Services, Inc.
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Fluid Dynamics of Drag”.
Professor Ascher M. Shapiro describes experiments to show that in a certain range of speeds the drag of a sphere decreases as the speed increases; that at low speed a smooth sphere has less drag than a rough sphere, while at high speeds it is just the reverse; that stream lining reduces drag in air, but increases drag in glycerine.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Quentin Brown, Kevin Smith and Educational Services, Inc.

results.title: How to reduce drag (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Quentin Brown, Kevin Smith and Education Services
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Fluid Dynamics of Drag”.
Professor Ascher M. Shapiro indicates the effect of body shape on drag; streamlining at high Reynolds Number; Bernoulli’s principle; boundary - layer stall; effect of turbulence on stall; effect of roughness; streamlining at low Reynolds Number; resolution of the paradoxes of Part I.

results.title: Fundamental concepts (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Fluid Dynamics of Drag”.
Professor Ascher M. Shapiro introduces concepts of continuous fluid, density and velocity at a point, body forces, surface forces, pressure, pressure gradient, viscous stress, viscosity; equations of fluid motion; limiting cases of low and high viscosity; Reynolds Number and dynamical similarity; pressure drag, friction drag and total drag.
results.description:
Episode of Series “Fluid Dynamics of Drag”.
Professor Ascher M. Shapiro introduces concepts of continuous fluid, density and velocity at a point, body forces, surface forces, pressure, pressure gradient, viscous stress, viscosity; equations of fluid motion; limiting cases of low and high viscosity; Reynolds Number and dynamical similarity; pressure drag, friction drag and total drag.

results.title: Engineering: flue gas analysis (Orsat apparatus)
results.creator_credit: Audio Productions and United States. Office of Education
results.brief_description: Setting up the Orsat gas analyzer; drawing in an air-free sample of flue gas; absorbing and measuring the amounts of carbon dioxide, oxygen and carbon monoxide in the sample; and how to calculate the amount of nitrogen.

results.title: Floyd Hyde
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “One Man”.
A portrait of the dynamic 45 year old artist-attorney, who is the popular and progressive Mayor of the city of Fresno, California. This is a large city with a population of 160,00 whose economy is dependent on the income generated by the fertile surrounding rural areas. Narrated by Barry Sullivan.

results.title: Flowers on a one way street
results.creator_credit: Robin Spry, Joseph Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Yorkville Avenue, Toronto, received newspaper prominence after it became what the papers called a “hippie haven”. This film records what happened after the young people staged demonstrations to have the street closed to traffic, and civic authorities used corresponding persuasions to keep it open as a necessary traffic artery. The main confrontation takes place at a council meeting in City Hall, to which spokesmen for the young people have come to present their case. Here the film provides opportunity to judge both their attitudes and those of the city administration. Music by The Beatles and Ravi Shankar. Photography by Douglas Kiefer and edited Christopher Cordeaux. (Awards: Chicago; New York).

results.title: Flowers at work
results.brief_description: Animation and time lapse cinematography show the physiology of flowers, various types of flowers, and their methods of pollination. The part played by insects in the process of cross-fertilisation is illustrated, and the structure and function of the sepals, petals, stamens, pistil, anthers, pollen grains, stle, and ovaries are studied. The film also shows some examples of how cultivation has modified the form of some flowers.

results.title: Flowering plants and their parts
results.creator_credit: Charles L. Finance, Stanley Croner and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basic Life Science”.
Relates the roots, stems and leaves of plants to plant growth and reproduction. Illustrates the ability of plants to adapt to their environment.
